design_intent.player_goal: Design and enforce security governance: policies, people controls, vendors, frameworks, and compliance proof.

trap_list.name: Policy vs Standard vs Procedure vs Guideline
trap_list.misconception: Policies, standards, procedures, and guidelines are interchangeable documents.
trap_list.fix: Policy = high-level mandatory intent; Standard = mandatory requirements; Procedure = mandatory steps; Guideline = optional advice.

trap_list.name: Centralized vs Decentralized governance
trap_list.misconception: Centralized and decentralized governance produce the same outcomes.
trap_list.fix: Centralized is top-down consistency/enforcement; decentralized is business-unit autonomy (often with uneven security).

trap_list.name: Exceptions aren’t permission to ignore risk
trap_list.misconception: If you can’t comply, you just note it and move on.
trap_list.fix: Exceptions should be scoped/time-bound, risk-assessed, include compensating controls, and have a remediation plan back to compliance.

trap_list.name: Change management is anti-outage engineering
trap_list.misconception: Change management is paperwork that slows engineers and can be skipped.
trap_list.fix: Change management prevents unplanned outages by enforcing impact analysis, testing, approval, rollback planning, and documentation.

trap_list.name: Admin-for-everyone is incident fuel
trap_list.misconception: Granting broad admin access reduces risk because work gets done faster.
trap_list.fix: Least privilege reduces blast radius; broad access + privilege creep increases attack surface and insider impact.

trap_list.name: Separation of duties vs Two-person control
trap_list.misconception: SoD and two-person control are the same thing.
trap_list.fix: SoD splits risky privilege combinations across roles; two-person control requires two people for one sensitive action.

trap_list.name: Due diligence vs Due care
trap_list.misconception: Due diligence and due care mean ‘being careful’ and can be used interchangeably.
trap_list.fix: Due diligence = learn/assess requirements/risks; Due care = implement and maintain effective controls that address them.

trap_list.name: Acknowledgment vs Attestation
trap_list.fix: Acknowledgment proves awareness; attestation asserts compliant behavior/practice (stronger, higher accountability).

trap_list.name: Vendor agreement soup (MSA/SLA/SOW/MOU/MOA)
trap_list.misconception: All contract documents do the same thing; only the SLA matters.
trap_list.fix: MSA sets umbrella terms; SLA defines service metrics/remedies; SOW/WO defines project work; MOU informal; MOA formal responsibilities; NDA confidentiality.

trap_list.name: CSF vs RMF
trap_list.misconception: CSF and RMF are the same framework.
trap_list.fix: CSF organizes risk into functions/categories for communication and posture; RMF is a step process for selecting/assessing controls and authorizing systems.

missions.name: Governance Foundations
missions.goal: Understand governance structures, authority, and how security aligns to business goals.

missions.name: Policy Stack & Exceptions
missions.goal: Build the policy ladder and handle exceptions without blowing up risk.

mechanics.twist: Confuse standards vs procedures and you lose streaks.

missions.name: Change Management Without Outages
missions.goal: Run change management like a reliability engineer: impact, test, implement, document.

missions.name: People Controls
missions.goal: Stop privilege creep, prevent fraud, and manage onboarding/offboarding cleanly.

mechanics.twist: Risky privilege combos appear like Tetris blocks.

missions.name: Third-Party Risk
missions.goal: Vet vendors, write the right agreements, monitor performance, and plan exits.

missions.name: Compliance & Frameworks
missions.goal: Know why compliance exists, how to prove it, and how frameworks guide the program.

mechanics.twist: Swap CSF/RMF and the ‘auditor’ gets cranky.

missions.name: Awareness & Culture
missions.goal: Turn humans from attack surface into sensor network—training, awareness, and phishing drills.

boss.name: Boss: The Audit That Bites
boss.premise: A merger, a new cloud vendor, and a board that wants proof. Build governance fast: approve an exception, ship a risky change safely, lock down privileges, and survive an external audit.

mechanics.phase_1: Create/align policy ladder + handle exception packet with compensating controls.
mechanics.phase_2: Run CAB: impact analysis, test, maintenance window, rollback plan, documentation updates.
mechanics.phase_3: Prove compliance: vendor contracts/audit rights, due diligence vs due care, CSF communication, and phishing readiness.

constraint_cards.name: Board Wants Metrics
constraint_cards.effect: Every encounter includes at least one question about evidence, reporting, or accountability.

constraint_cards.name: Legacy Anchor
constraint_cards.effect: Exception/compensating control questions become more common; scope/time-boxing matters.

constraint_cards.name: Remote-First Workforce
constraint_cards.effect: Awareness + access lifecycle questions are weighted; onboarding/offboarding gets tricky.

modes.name: Policy Duel
modes.description: Fast-paced identification of the right governance document or control for a situation.

rules.scoring: Correct + speed bonus; wrong triggers a trap card.
